review.title: Ischemic Stroke Identification Based on EEG and EOG using 1D Convolutional Neural Network and Batch Normalization
review.abstract: In 2015, stroke was the number one cause of death in Indonesia. The majority type of stroke is ischemic. The standard tool for diagnosing stroke is CT-Scan. For developing countries like Indonesia, the availability of CT-Scan is very limited and still relatively expensive. Because of the availability, another device that potential to diagnose stroke in Indonesia is EEG. Ischemic stroke occurs because of obstruction that can make the cerebral blood flow (CBF) on a person with stroke has become lower than CBF on a normal person (control) so that the EEG signal have a deceleration. On this study, we perform the ability of 1D Convolutional Neural Network (1DCNN) to construct classification model that can distinguish the EEG and EOG stroke data from EEG and EOG control data. To accelerate training process our model we use Batch Normalization. Involving 62 person data object and from leave one out the scenario with five times repetition of measurement we obtain the average of accuracy 0.86 (F-Score 0.861) only at 200 epoch. This result is better than all over shallow and popular classifiers as the comparator (the best result of accuracy 0.69 and F-Score 0.72 ). The feature used in our study were only 24 handcrafted feature with simple feature extraction process.

sections.heading: 2 Data, Features, Classifiers, and Batch
sections.text: Normalization This section describes the data, characteristics and several classifiers to be compared in our studies.

sections.heading: 2.1 Data
sections.text: We provide and use primary EEG data recorded through our collaboration with Pusat Otak Nasional (PON) or the National Brain Center Hospital, Jakarta. For data control, we use 32 patients with stroke and 30 normal subjects. For this study, we use two class markers: "Stroke" and "Normal." For each data object, signals from 33 channels were recorded. For data acquisition, we use two EEG tools. One machine with the brand Xltek and the other is Biologic. The sampling rate of the EEG signal for Xltek is 512Hz, and for Biologic, we use 512Hz for some data and 256Hz for the other. The duration for each EEG measurement was a total of 15 minutes. In this study, we use only 2 channels EEG (C3 and OZ) and 2 electrooculography channels (left EOG and right EOG).

sections.heading: 2.2 Features
sections.text: This study uses 24 "handmade" characteristics. All these characteristics are the characteristics that a part of the characteristics was used in [9]. Unlike [9] of this study, it is not about the band frequency of the delta. In detail, the characteristics consist of: 1. Relative power for four band frequencies: Delta (0.5 − 4 Hz), Theta (4 − 8 Hz), Alpha (8 − 13 Hz) and Beta (13 − 20 Hz). This relative performance characteristic amounted to 12 characteristics consisting of: (f01) C3 delta, (f02) C3 theta, (f03) C3 alpha, (f04) C3 beta, (f05) EOG delta, (f07) EOG delta, (f07) EOG delta, (f08) EOG variation (f08) EOG value, (f09) OZ delta, (f10) OZ value.

sections.heading: 2.3 Classifiers
sections.text: In this study, we compare 1D Convolutional Neural Network (1DCNN) with several shallow and popular classifiers. This section briefly describes 1DCNN and the list of shallow classifiers as a benchmark.

In our study, the 1D convolutional operation is useful to extract the important local trait between the adjacent element values of the feature vector. On the other hand, the 1D pooling operation is viewed globally and the information value for each important local trait is generalized. sections.heading: 2.4 Batch Normalization
sections.text: Many layers of deep neural architecture complicate the training process. Deep architecture requires a low learning rate and much more time to train. It is difficult to train models with saturating nonlinearity on deep neural architecture.This condition is called an internal covariate layer problem. One of the techniques used to solve this problem is the normalization input level. As mentioned on [7], the main goal of batch normalization is to achieve a stable distribution of activation values during the training. Batch normalization applies normalization techniques for each training minibatch.For general algorithm steps of batch normalization according to (2) to (7).For each equation, we represent every aspect of the normalization process. Equation (4) is minibatch mean, Equation (5) is minibatch variance, Equation (6) is normalization task, and Equation (7) is scale and layer process that can be reduced to the normalization process as a learning process and from several learning layers to the normalization process.

sections.heading: 3 Methodology
sections.text: In this section, four main steps of our methodology are described (Fig. 4).

sections.heading: 3.1 Data Acquisition
sections.text: As already mentioned, we are working in collaboration with PON Hospital, Jakarta. Using two EEG tools (with another brand, Xltek and Biologic), EEG signals from 62 people are recorded as object data. The proportion of stroke data is 32 and for normal data 30. The age range of the data objects is between 29 and 72 years, 37 people male and 25 people female. In this study, we also assisted two neurologists in diagnosing the EEG signal and the stroke severity of the patient. For each recording, the task took a total of 15 minutes. For each EEG measurement, there are five event channels. Events include: open eyes without stimulation, closed eyes without stimulation and closed eyes with a flash of light stimulation in three variants of frequencies (5 Hz, 10 Hz and 15 Hz). The sampling rate was used for recording with Xltek: EZ 5, EZ 5, EZ 5, EZ 5, EZ 5.

sections.heading: 3.2 Preprocessing
sections.text: From the literature it is known that the ischemic stroke is caused by obstruction. Obstruction results in the CBF value of the stroke patient being much lower than the CBF value of a normal person. Low CBF values have an influence on the deceleration of the EEG signal of stroke patients. Therefore, the focus of the analysis of the EEG signals should be on the slow wave signals. Several other studies analyzing the frequency bands include four large waves with band frequencies below 30 Hz (1 − 4Hz delta, 4 − 8Hz theta, 8 − 12Hz alpha and 12 − 30Hz beta). The lowest sampling rate in the EEG recording in our study is 256 Hz. With the sampling rate of 256Hz, we can obtain PSD from the band frequency between 0 Hz and 128Hz alpha, which of course supports the action to make the EEG stroke data different from the EEG control of the EEG method (to the 61er and to the 61er).

sections.heading: 3.3 Feature Extraction
sections.text: After pre-processing the data, we move on to the feature extraction phase. Input of this stage is 4 channels (C3, Oz, LEOG and REOG), 62x57600 raw data. As a result, only 24 features result for each data object. The final data structure for the feature in our study is 62x24. Our "handmade" features as a result of this phase consist of relative power band frequency, variance, correlation aspect, curtosis, entropy, spectral mean and exponent of fractal.8 / 13

sections.heading: 3.4 Classifier Evaluation
sections.text: In this study, we have only 62 data objects. This size is too small if we used a k-fold cross-validation scenario with a limited number of k. In this situation, we use Leave One Out (LOO) cross-validation techniques to evaluate the performance of each classifier in experiments.The LOO scenario specified a scheme: one data as a test and the other data as a training in each round. In this study, each round has 1 data object as a data test and the remaining 61 data objects as training data. This condition was repeated 62 laps, so that for each time recorded in test data and 61 times as training data. In our evaluation, this 62 times LOO (full round) was repeated five times. For each complete repetition, each parameter of matrix performance was calculated and then evaluated against the average.

sections.heading: 4 Experiment Result
sections.text: Our experiment runs on two operating system environments, Ubuntu 14.04 for implementing 1DCNN and Windows 8 to run Orange for data mining applications. Computer hardware was used in this study and has a specification a quad core i7 CPU (clocked size 2.4GHz) with 4GB of RAM. The experiment rated 1DCNN on two different epochs (100 and 200). Table I shows the performance parameter results for each epoch and all of the comparator classifiers. Increasing epoch value accompanied by improvements in the performance parameter values of 1DCNN. From the experiment with epoch 100 and epoch 200, we get the average accuracy results are 0.829 and 0.861. These results obtain an improvement in accuracy to compare the best performance of the comparator (just 0.69, Naive Bayes). Descending order by the average accuracy based on the performance are 1DCNN, Naive Bayes, Naive 200 Bayes, and 861 we are the accuracy.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: The results of the experiment show that 1DCNN has managed to be the best model for distinguishing the task between the EEG stroke data and the EEG control data. In this study, we apply techniques of early stop and batch normalization to speed up the training process of our classification model. 1DCNN's leave-one-out scenario achieved an average accuracy of 0.86 (F score 0.861 and precision 0.870), which was achieved in just 200 epochs and using a 24 "handcrafted" function that focused on four channels, 2 EEG channels and 2 EOG channels. Comparing the best result with a flat classifier (Naive Bayes), 1DCNN achieves an improvement of about 16.8%. From this result, it was shown that EEG is very potential and possible to distinguish a person having a stroke from the normal population. 10 / 13Virtual Class Prediction NNDB CNN CNN CNN CNN.
